 In my opinion your proposal amounts to a radical expansion of the criminal doctrine of accessory liability. I want to use my state’s jury instructions to illustrate this point. The instructions will be “in italics.” 
 
 Let’s assume a gun is used to commit a murder. Here is where criminal liability starts:
 
 The principal in the first degree—the gunman who actually pulls the trigger: “A principal in the first degree is the person who actually commits the crime.”

 Those who helped, counseled, or advised beforehand but who are not present when the crime is committed can also be held liable as an “accessory before the fact” (for example, a person hiring someone to kill their spouse, or someone providing the gun to the killer beforehand while both knowing that the crime will and agreeing that the crime should happen):
